result.execSummary:
The defendant Bryson T Tompkins was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Obstruct Officer - Substantial Bodily Harm/Soft Tissue Injury, a class H felony, Wisconsin Statutes 946.41(2r).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes:
Defendant IS eligible for Challenge Incarceration and Substance Abuse program after serving 2 years of initial confinement.
Consecutive to: 15CF239

superMiscConds.notes: Restitution of $189.98 payable to Chelsea C. (to be paid as a Condition of Extended Supervision)

Court costs and DNA to be paid as a Condition of Extended Supervision.

If Probation/Extended Supervision is revoked and/or a prison term ordered, outstanding financial obligations shall be collected pursuant to statutory provisions, including deductions from inmate prison monies.  If discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant and in favor of restitution victims and government entities for outstanding financial obligations.  Collections may include income assignment.

Maintain full time employment and/or school.
Obtain GED or HSED.
Submit to an AODA Assessment and follow through with any treatment recommended.

Maintain absolute sobriety.
Submit to random alcohol/drug screens.
Not to use or possess of alcohol or controlled substances without a valid prescription or any drug paraphernalia.
Any valid prescription drugs must be taken only in the manner in which they are prescribed.
Inform Agent of all prescriptions.
Follow through with any treatment/counseling recommended.
Provide DNA sample if not previously done.

records.descr: Remittitur/Court of Appeals dec & order affirming

records.addlTxt:
Certified Copy.
Summary disposition orders may not be cited in any court of the state as precedant or authority, except for the limited purposes specificied in Wis. Stat. Rule 809.23(3).

In these consolidated cases, Bryson T. Tompkins appeals from judgments of conviction and an order denying his motion for postconviction relief.  He seeks to either vacate his judgments or obtain an evidentiary hearing on hi plea withdrawal request.  Based upon our review of the briefs and record, we conclude at conference that this case is appropriate for summary disposition.  We Affirm.

IT IS ORDERED that the judgments and order of the circuit court are summarily affirmed, pursuant to Wis. Stat. Rule 809.21
IT IS FURTHER ORDERED:  that this summary disposition order will not be published.
records.descr: Court of Appeals decision & order affirming

In these consolidated cases, Bryson T. Tompkins appeals from judgments of conviction and an order denying his motion for postconviction relief.  He seeks to either vacate his judgments or obtain an evidentiary hearing on his plea withdrawal request.  Based upon our review of the briefs, we conclude that this case is appropriate for summary disposition.  We Affirm.

IT IS ORDERED that the judgments an order of the circuit court are summarily affirmed, pursuant to WIS. STAT. RULE 809.21.
IT IS FUTHER ORDERED that this summary disposition order will not be published.

Defendant Bryson T Tompkins in court by video from Columbia Correctional with attorney Trisha R Stewart Martin.  Lesli S Boese and Shawn Woller appeared for the State of Wisconsin. Court addresses post conviction motion filed by the defense. Atty. Martin makes statements. State makes statements. Based on the statements made as to point 9 of the motion, the Court will order an amended judgment of conviction to read obstructing an officer rather than resisting an officer. For reasons set out on the record, the Court will deny the remainder of the motion in its entirety and allow Atty. Martin to refile the motion with more specificity. Atty. Martin to file the new motion by 4/6/18. State to file response by 4/23/18. Defendant to appear by video for the next hearing.  Motion hearing scheduled for May 2, 2018 at 02:00 pm. filed by the State
filed by the State
with Elements of criminal offenses to which plea is being entered.

Defendant Bryson T Tompkins in court, in custody, with attorney John Paul Marchan.   Shawn N Woller appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Case called for 12 person jury trial.  Court will empanel 20 jurors.  Motion in limine addressed.  Defendant to testify to four prior convictions.  Court will grant exclusion of witnesses during voir dire.  Court will address challenge for cause outside presence of jury.  Defense to prepare a jury instruction on what a warrant is.  Court will allow note taking.  Court will not allow questions by the jurors. Defense requests a recess. The defendant requests to enter a plea. Defense to complete the plea forms. Case recalled. Defense puts statements on the record regarding the plea questionnaire and waiver of rights form. Amended Information filed.  Reading waived.  Defendant enters a guilty plea to Count 2.  Court finds defendant guilty. Ct. 1 and Ct. 3 dismissed and read-in.  Defense requests a separate date for sentencing. Court grants request. State and Defense are not requesting a Presentence Investigation. Court will set a sentencing date in 2 - 3 weeks.  Sentencing hearing scheduled for October 30, 2015 at 02:30 pm.
filed by Attorney Marchan.
filed by Attorney Marchan.

Defendant Bryson T Tompkins in court, in custody, with attorney John Paul Marchan.   Shawn N Woller appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  The parties have not reached a resolution and  are ready to proceed to trial.  The trial will begin at 8:15 a.m.  The Court will address any motion in limine at the time.  The trial is expected to last one day but may go into a second day.

Signed by Judge Aprahamian on 9/25/15.  The Court orders that Waukesha County Jail allow Attorney John Paul Marchan a professional non-contact meeting with Mr. Tompkins on Saturday, September 26, 2015 beginning at 2:00 p.m.  It is further ordered that the professional visit not be by video and that the professional visit last as long as the defense needs in order to prepare this matter, up to four hours.  At which time, Attorney Marchan can, if necessary, rely upon avilable times on Sunday.
